attributes.comment:
To Whom It May Concern,

Although I understand the need for CIS to modernize its business from processes,
to technology, to application timelines, I feel as though the astronomical rate
increases are unjustified. It merely seems as though CIS has taken the costs of
the interim benefits for most of the applications and rolled it into the new
application fees.

As an immigrant I can honestly tell you the public perception of CIS is poor and
will likely get worse with the fee increases. Also, as a proud immigrant, I would
pay reasonable fees for immigration services BUT they must be justified. Up until
now, CIS has failed in customer service, application procedures, waittimes,
backlogs, and any other customer facing process you can think of. I know the
excuse is that the new fees will improve the system, but nothing in this agency's
history shows a need to service its customers while protecting the USA. What
guarantees do we have - as the public- that the fee increases will result in a 20%
reduction of processing times? Seriously, the processing times for most
applications today do not fall within the timeline the President asked for to begin
with. How do I know the USCIS will follow through?

Finally, the other area of concern is the percentage of increase. A citizenship
application would cost approximately $700 (including biometrics). That is a huge
burden on the public. Keep in mind that non of the fee is refundable should
something go wrong (whether it is a USCIS error or not). I can honestly tell you
that his fee is unaffordable to most individuals, and the fact that we are speaking
out against the fee increases does not mean we do not value the US immigration
benefits bestowed on us.

My solution would be to take Congress up on its offer and request they pay for the
expansion efforts of USCIS over the next several years. If the billions of dollars
were supplied, then USCIS could increase the fee - not to recover the lost interim
benefit applications, but rather to reflect the true increase of inflation and the true
cost of application processing. Another option is for USCIS to implement the
changes they propose the increased fees would facilitate first, then after proving to
the general public that they are an efficient and functioning agency, they can raise
the fees as much as they like. No one will complain if they know the system and
processes actually work.

Regards,
Mo.
attributes.title: Comment Submitted By Mo Jibril
